|Title=Know how to treat simple acute pyelonephritis
|Description=None
|Heading=Management
|Contributors=Maxime Vallée, Alice Faure
|Order=11}}



● Except in special cases of excessive vomiting preventing the use of oral antibiotics or social isolation preventing outpatient treatment, simple ANP must be treated as an outpatient.

● First-line antibiotic treatment is based on fluoroquinolones for 7 days (unless antibiotics in this class have been taken within 3 months).

● In rare cases of uncomplicated ANP requiring hospital management, treatment with IV C3G should be preferred and will be adapted after the ECBU.

● Progress should be rapidly satisfactory within 48-72 hours; in the event of failure, imaging must be performed and the patient admitted to hospital.

question.question: What is the recommended initial treatment approach for simple acute pyelonephritis (ANP) in outpatient settings, unless contraindicated?
question.option_a: Oral antibiotics for 7 days, typically a fluoroquinolone, unless taken within the last 3 months.
question.option_b: Intravenous C3G for 7 days as a first-line treatment.
question.option_c: Hospitalization with continuous intravenous antibiotics for a minimum of 10 days.
question.option_d: Oral antibiotics for 3 days, followed by a re-evaluation.
